user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_BinSemFlush:
```c
int32 OS_BinSemFlush(osal_id_t sem_id)
{
    OS_object_token_t token;
    int32             return_code;

    /* Check Parameters */
    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_NONE, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, sem_id, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return_code = OS_BinSemFlush_Impl(&token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_BinSemFlush:
int32 OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_lock_mode_t lock_mode, osal_objtype_t idtype, osal_id_t id, OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int32 return_code;

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit(lock_mode, idtype, token);
    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return return_code;
    }

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdToArrayIndex(idtype, id, &token->obj_idx);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        token->obj_id = id;

        /*
         * The "ConvertToken" routine will return with the global lock
         * in a state appropriate for returning to the caller, as indicated
         * by the "check_mode" parameter.
         *
         * Note If this operation fails, then it always unlocks the global for
         * all check_mode's other than NONE.
         */
        return_code = OS_ObjectIdConvertToken(token);
    }

    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel(token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
...
int32 OS_BinSemFlush_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    OS_impl_binsem_internal_record_t *sem;

    sem = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_bin_sem_table, *token);

    /* Lock the mutex ( not the table! ) */
    if (OS_Posix_BinSemAcquireMutex(&sem->id) != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return OS_SEM_FAILURE;
    }

    /* increment the flush counter.  Any other threads that are
     * currently pending in SemTake() will see the counter change and
     * return _without_ modifying the semaphore count.
     */
    ++sem->flush_request;

    /* unblock all threads that are be waiting on this sem */
    pthread_cond_broadcast(&(sem->cv));

    pthread_mutex_unlock(&(sem->id));

    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
typedef uint32 osal_id_t
...
typedef int32_t   int32
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No explicit compiler language extensions are present in the provided code. I inspected the fragments for common documented compiler extensions (tokens and constructs such as __attribute__, __asm / asm, __extension__, __builtin_*, typeof, statement-expressions ({ ... }), labels-as-values, nested functions, GCC/Clang-specific __attribute__((...)) uses, or other vendor-specific keywords) and found none.

Reasons the shown fragments do NOT need investigation for Rule 1.2:
- Function definitions and calls (OS_BinSemFlush, OS_ObjectIdGetById, OS_BinSemFlush_Impl) use standard C syntax and standard typedef aliases (int32/int32_t, osal_id_t). These are not compiler extensions.
- Use of POSIX threading APIs (pthread_cond_broadcast, pthread_mutex_unlock) are library/API calls, not language extensions.
- The pre/post-increment (++sem->flush_request), pointer dereferences, and macro-like invocations (OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(...)) are ordinary C usage; no extension tokens are present in the shown expansions.

Note/limitation: Some macros or functions referenced but not defined here (for example OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET, OS_impl_bin_sem_table, OS_Posix_BinSemAcquireMutex) could internally use compiler extensions. Those implementations are outside the provided code; they would need to be inspected directly to determine whether they use documented compiler extensions. Based on only the provided source lines, there are no explicit language-extension usages to report.
